subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization: Solving Matrix Powers
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to diagonalize a matrix and compute its powers.
problemHtml: Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A = [[2, -3], [1, 4]], then use them to diagonalize A. Finally, compute A3.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Find the characteristic polynomial", "mathHtml": "\[p(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I) = 0\]", "explanation": "The characteristic polynomial helps us find the eigenvalues." }, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors", "mathHtml": "\[\begin{align*} \lambda_1 &= 3, &v_1 &= [1, -1], \\ \lambda_2 &= 1, &v_2 &= [1, 1]. \end{align*}\]", "explanation": "The eigenvalues and eigenvectors are crucial for diagonalization." }, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Diagonalize the matrix", "mathHtml": "\[P^{-1}AP = D\], where D is a diagonal matrix.", "explanation": "By diagonalizing the matrix, we can easily compute its powers." }, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Compute the third power of A", "mathHtml": "\[A^3 = PDP^{-1}\], where D^3 is a diagonal matrix.", "explanation": "Computing the power of a diagonalized matrix is straightforward." } ],
intuition: Diagonalization allows us to simplify complex matrix operations by breaking them down into easier-to-compute diagonalized matrices.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization of a Matrix
contentHtml: In linear algebra, diagonalization is a powerful technique to transform a matrix into its canonical form.

problem.statementHtml: Given a square matrix A, find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to diagonalize it.
hints: Hint: Start by finding the characteristic polynomial

steps.explanation: This is the polynomial whose roots are the eigenvalues.

steps.description: Compute the eigenvalues by solving the characteristic equation
steps.explanation: The eigenvalue is the value of x that makes P(x) equal to zero.

steps.description: Find the eigenvectors by solving (A - λI)v = 0
steps.explanation: The eigenvectors are the non-zero vectors that, when transformed by A, result in a scaled version of themselves.

steps.description: Diagonalize the matrix using the eigenvalues and eigenvectors
steps.explanation: The diagonalized matrix is the product of the eigenvectors and eigenvalues.

intuition: Diagonalization helps us understand the underlying structure of a matrix, making it easier to compute powers and perform other operations.

title: Diagonalization of Matrices
contentHtml: When possible, a matrix P can be diagonalized by finding its eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

problem.statementHtml: Given the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\], find its diagonalization.
hints: Find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of A
Use these to construct a diagonal matrix D

To diagonalize A, we first need to find its eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Let λ be an eigenvalue with corresponding eigenvector v.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Diagonalization: Solving Matrix Powers
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to diagonalize a matrix and compute its powers.
problemHtml: Given the matrix A = \[\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 4 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\], find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors, then use them to diagonalize A.",
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Find the characteristic polynomial", "mathHtml": "\[p(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I)\]", "explanation": "We'll use the characteristic polynomial to find the eigenvalues."}, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Compute the eigenvalues", "mathHtml": "\[\begin{aligned} p(1) &= 0 \\ p(-1) &= 0 \end{aligned}\]", "explanation": "The eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial."}, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Find the eigenvectors", "mathHtml": "\[\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\] and \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]", "explanation": "The eigenvectors are the non-zero vectors that, when transformed by A, result in scaled versions of themselves."}, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Diagonalize A", "mathHtml": "\[P^{-1}AP = D\]", "explanation": "We'll use the eigenvalues and eigenvectors to create a diagonal matrix D."}, {"stepNumber": 5, "description": "Compute the powers of A", "mathHtml": "\[A^n = PDP^{-1}\]", "explanation": "Now that we have the diagonalized form, computing matrix powers becomes much easier."} ],
finalAnswer: The eigenvalues are 1 and -1, and the eigenvectors are \[\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 1 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\] and \[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ -2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]." },
intuition: Diagonalization allows us to simplify complex matrix operations by breaking them down into smaller, more manageable pieces.
